snippet: A defendant accused of insulting Thailand’s king was punished not only for what he said during a speech, but also for making a gesture of being muzzled.
abstract: Thai court sentences former protest leader Yossawarit Chuklom to two years in prison for implying, but not overtly expressing, criticism of King Bhumibol Adulyadej during 2010 speech; ruling appears to broaden interpretation of Thailand’s already restrictive lese-majeste law, which prohibits offending king.
lead_paragraph: A defendant accused of insulting Thailand’s king was punished not only for what he said during a speech, but also for making a gesture of being muzzled.

headline.seo: In Thailand, a Broader Definition of Insulting Royalty
headline.main: In Thailand, a Broader Definition of Insulting Royalty
headline.print_headline: Thai’s Gesture Spoke Volumes Against King, Court Rules
